conversation.content: Wait, who are you? I didn't see you come in.
Just someone passing through. You seemed deep in thought about that equation on your screen—it's a fascinating approach to quantum entanglement, by the way.
How did you even see my screen from over there?

Good eyesight and pattern recognition. The way you're structuring those variables suggests you're trying to solve for non-local correlations, right? Most people would use Bell's theorem as a starting point.
That's... exactly what I'm working on. Are you a physicist?
Not exactly. I pick things up here and there. Your methodology is unconventional but it might actually work better than the standard approach for what you're trying to prove.
You can't just "pick up" quantum mechanics. Who sent you?
Nobody sent me. Sometimes people just share interests. Though I admit quantum mechanics isn't typical coffee shop conversation material.
This is classified research. You shouldn't even know what you're looking at.

[furious] Classified? You're working on this in a public café with your screen facing the window! If it's so secret, maybe exercise some basic operational security instead of blaming random strangers.
I... okay, fair point. But you still haven't explained who you are.
Someone who recognizes innovative thinking when they see it. Your approach to the measurement problem is genuinely novel—you're treating observer effect as a variable rather than a constant.
How could you possibly deduce that from a glimpse at my screen?
The same way you can tell a song from three notes if you know music. Pattern recognition is pattern recognition, whether it's physics or anything else.
Are you going to report this to someone?
[very sincerely] Report what? That someone is advancing human understanding of quantum mechanics? I'd rather see where your research leads. Knowledge should be celebrated, not suppressed.
[very slowly] So you're just... a random genius who happened to walk by?
Genius is overstating it. Curious and observant, maybe. Your work is the impressive thing here—I'm just someone who can appreciate what you're accomplishing.
This is the strangest conversation I've ever had.
[sleepily] Strange conversations often lead to the best breakthroughs. Keep working on that equation—you're closer to the solution than you think. The third variable needs inverting, by the way.
